sn47.16:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā uttiyo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā uttiyo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn47.16:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Uttiya went up to the Buddha … and asked him,

sn47.16:1.3.pli: “sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammaṃ desetu, yamahaṃ bhagavato dhammaṃ sutvā eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto vihareyyan”ti.
sn47.16:1.3.eng: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”

sn47.16:1.4.pli: “Tasmātiha tvaṃ, uttiya, ādimeva visodhehi kusalesu dhammesu.
sn47.16:1.4.eng: “Well then, Uttiya, you should purify the starting point of skillful qualities.

sn47.16:1.5.eng: What is the starting point of skillful qualities?

sn47.16:1.6.eng: Well purified ethics and correct view.

sn47.16:1.7.pli: Yato ca kho te, uttiya, sīlañca suvisuddhaṃ bhavissati, diṭṭhi ca ujukā, tato tvaṃ, uttiya, sīlaṃ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bhāveyyāsi.
sn47.16:1.7.eng: When your ethics are well purified and your view is correct, you should develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, depending on and grounded on ethics.

sn47.16:2.2.pli: Idha tvaṃ, uttiya, kāye kāyānupassī viharāhi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.16:2.2.eng: Meditate observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.16:2.3.eng: Meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.16:2.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharāhi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.16:2.5.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.16:2.6.pli: Yato kho tvaṃ, uttiya, sīlaṃ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ime cattāro satipaṭṭhāne evaṃ bhāvessasi, tato tvaṃ, uttiya, gamissasi maccudheyyassa pāran”ti.
sn47.16:2.6.eng: When you develop these four kinds of mindfulness meditation, depending on and grounded on ethics, you’ll cross beyond Death’s dominion.”

sn47.16:3.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā uttiyo bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
sn47.16:3.1.eng: And then Venerable Uttiya approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.

sn47.16:3.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā uttiyo eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
sn47.16:3.2.eng: Then Uttiya, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

sn47.16:3.3.pli: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
sn47.16:3.3.eng: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”

sn47.16:3.4.pli: Aññataro ca panāyasmā uttiyo arahataṃ ahosīti.
sn47.16:3.4.eng: And Venerable Uttiya became one of the perfected.

sn47.17:1.1.pli: “Cattārome, bhikkhave, satipaṭṭhānā bhāvitā bahulīkatā ariyā niyyānikā niyyanti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya.
sn47.17:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when these four kinds of mindfulness meditation are developed and cultivated they are noble and emancipating, and bring one who practices them to the complete ending of suffering.

sn47.17:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.17:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.17:1.4.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.17:1.6.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.17:1.6.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.17:1.7.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvitā bahulīkatā ariyā niyyānikā niyyanti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāyā”ti.
sn47.17:1.7.eng: When these four kinds of mindfulness meditation are developed and cultivated they are noble and emancipating, and bring one who practices them to the complete ending of suffering.”

sn47.18:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā uruvelāyaṃ viharati najjā nerañjarāya tīre ajapālanigrodhe paṭhamābhisambuddho.
sn47.18:1.1.eng: At one time, when he was first awakened, the Buddha was staying in Uruvelā at the goatherd’s banyan tree on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.

sn47.18:1.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavato rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
sn47.18:1.2.eng: Then as he was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,

sn47.18:1.3.pli: “ekāyanvāyaṃ maggo sattānaṃ visuddhiyā sokaparidevānaṃ samatikkamāya dukkhadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamāya ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya, yadidaṃ—cattāro satipaṭṭhānā.
sn47.18:1.3.eng: “The four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the path to convergence. They are in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to discover the system, and to realize extinguishment.

sn47.18:2.2.pli: Kāye vā bhikkhu kāyānupassī vihareyya ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.18:2.2.eng: A mendicant would meditate observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.18:2.3.eng: Or they’d meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.18:2.5.pli: dhammesu vā bhikkhu dhammānupassī vihareyya ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.18:2.5.eng: or principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.18:2.6.pli: Ekāyanvāyaṃ maggo sattānaṃ visuddhiyā sokaparidevānaṃ samatikkamāya dukkhadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamāya ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya, yadidaṃ—cattāro satipaṭṭhānā”ti.
sn47.18:2.6.eng: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the path to convergence. They are in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to discover the system, and to realize extinguishment.”

sn47.18:3.1.pli: Atha kho brahmā sahampati bhagavato cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva kho brahmaloke antarahito bhagavato purato pāturahosi.
sn47.18:3.1.eng: Then the divinity Sahampati knew what the Buddha was thinking. As easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he vanished from the realm of divinity and reappeared in front of the Buddha.

sn47.18:3.2.pli: Atha kho brahmā sahampati ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn47.18:3.2.eng: He arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said:

sn47.18:3.3.eng: “That’s so true, Blessed One! That’s so true, Holy One!

sn47.18:3.4.pli: Ekāyanvāyaṃ, bhante, maggo sattānaṃ visuddhiyā sokaparidevānaṃ samatikkamāya dukkhadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamāya ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya, yadidaṃ—cattāro satipaṭṭhānā.
sn47.18:3.4.eng: Sir, the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the path to convergence. They are in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to discover the system, and to realize extinguishment.

sn47.18:4.2.pli: Kāye vā, bhante, bhikkhu kāyānupassī vihareyya ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.18:4.2.eng: A mendicant would meditate observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.18:4.3.eng: Or they’d meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.18:4.5.pli: dhammesu vā, bhante, bhikkhu dhammānupassī vihareyya ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.18:4.5.eng: or principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.18:4.6.pli: Ekāyanvāyaṃ, bhante, maggo sattānaṃ visuddhiyā sokaparidevānaṃ samatikkamāya dukkhadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamāya ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya, yadidaṃ—cattāro satipaṭṭhānā”ti.
sn47.18:4.6.eng: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the path to convergence. They are in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to discover the system, and to realize extinguishment.”

sn47.18:5.1.eng: That’s what the divinity Sahampati said.

sn47.18:5.2.eng: Then he went on to say:

sn47.18:6.1.eng: “The compassionate one, <j>who sees the ending of rebirth,

sn47.18:6.3.eng: By this path people crossed over before,

sn47.19:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sumbhesu viharati sedakaṃ nāma sumbhānaṃ nigamo.
sn47.19:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sumbhas, near the town of the Sumbhas named Sedaka.

sn47.19:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

sn47.19:1.3.pli: “bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, caṇḍālavaṃsiko caṇḍālavaṃsaṃ ussāpetvā medakathālikaṃ antevāsiṃ āmantesi:
sn47.19:1.3.eng: “Once upon a time, mendicants, a pole acrobat of the corpse-workers set up the bamboo pole of his tribe and said to his apprentice Medakathālikā,

sn47.19:1.4.pli: ‘ehi tvaṃ, samma medakathālike, caṇḍālavaṃsaṃ abhiruhitvā mama uparikhandhe tiṭṭhāhī’ti.
sn47.19:1.4.eng: ‘Come now, dear Medakathālikā, climb up the bamboo pole and stand on my shoulders.’

sn47.19:1.5.pli: ‘Evaṃ, ācariyā’ti kho, bhikkhave, medakathālikā antevāsī caṇḍālavaṃsikassa paṭissutvā caṇḍālavaṃsaṃ abhiruhitvā ācariyassa uparikhandhe aṭṭhāsi.
sn47.19:1.5.eng: ‘Yes, tutor,’ she replied. She climbed up the bamboo pole and stood on her tutor’s shoulders.

sn47.19:1.6.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, caṇḍālavaṃsiko medakathālikaṃ antevāsiṃ etadavoca:
sn47.19:1.6.eng: Then the pole acrobat of the corpse-workers said to Medakathālikā,

sn47.19:1.7.pli: ‘tvaṃ, samma medakathālike, mamaṃ rakkha, ahaṃ taṃ rakkhissāmi.
sn47.19:1.7.eng: ‘You look after me, dear Medakathālikā, and I’ll look after you.

sn47.19:1.8.pli: Evaṃ mayaṃ aññamaññaṃ guttā aññamaññaṃ rakkhitā sippāni ceva dassessāma, lābhañca lacchāma, sotthinā ca caṇḍālavaṃsā orohissāmā’ti.
sn47.19:1.8.eng: That’s how, guarding and looking after each other, we’ll display our skill, collect our fee, and get down safely from the bamboo pole.’

sn47.19:1.9.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhikkhave, medakathālikā antevāsī caṇḍālavaṃsikaṃ etadavoca:
sn47.19:1.9.eng: When he said this, Medakathālikā said to her teacher,

sn47.19:1.11.pli: Tvaṃ, ācariya, attānaṃ rakkha, ahaṃ attānaṃ rakkhissāmi.
sn47.19:1.11.eng: You should look after yourself, and I’ll look after myself.

sn47.19:1.12.pli: Evaṃ mayaṃ attaguttā attarakkhitā sippāni ceva dassessāma, lābhañca lacchāma, sotthinā ca caṇḍālavaṃsā orohissāmā’”ti.
sn47.19:1.12.eng: That’s how, guarding and looking after ourselves, we’ll display our skill, collect our fee, and get down safely from the bamboo pole.’

sn47.19:2.1.pli: “So tattha ñāyo”ti bhagavā etadavoca, “yathā medakathālikā antevāsī ācariyaṃ avoca.
sn47.19:2.1.eng: That’s the way,” said the Buddha. “It’s just as Medakathālikā said to her tutor.

sn47.19:2.2.eng: Thinking ‘I’ll look after myself,’ you should cultivate mindfulness meditation.

sn47.19:2.3.eng: Thinking ‘I’ll look after others,’ you should cultivate mindfulness meditation.

sn47.19:2.4.pli: Attānaṃ, bhikkhave, rakkhanto paraṃ rakkhati, paraṃ rakkhanto attānaṃ rakkhati.
sn47.19:2.4.eng: Looking after yourself, you look after others; and looking after others, you look after yourself.

sn47.19:3.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, attānaṃ rakkhanto paraṃ rakkhati?
sn47.19:3.1.eng: And how do you look after others by looking after yourself?

sn47.19:3.2.eng: By development, cultivation, and practice of meditation.

sn47.19:3.3.pli: evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, attānaṃ rakkhanto paraṃ rakkhati.

sn47.19:3.4.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, paraṃ rakkhanto attānaṃ rakkhati?
sn47.19:3.4.eng: And how do you look after yourself by looking after others?

sn47.19:3.5.eng: By acceptance, harmlessness, love, and sympathy.

sn47.19:3.6.pli: evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, paraṃ rakkhanto attānaṃ rakkhati.

sn47.19:3.7.eng: Thinking ‘I’ll look after myself,’ you should cultivate mindfulness meditation.

sn47.19:3.8.eng: Thinking ‘I’ll look after others,’ you should cultivate mindfulness meditation.

sn47.19:3.9.pli: Attānaṃ, bhikkhave, rakkhanto paraṃ rakkhati, paraṃ rakkhanto attānaṃ rakkhatī”ti.
sn47.19:3.9.eng: Looking after yourself, you look after others; and looking after others, you look after yourself.”

sn47.2:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati ambapālivane.
sn47.2:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, in Ambapālī’s mango grove.

sn47.2:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

sn47.2:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant should live mindful and aware.

sn47.2:2.2.eng: This is my instruction to you.

sn47.2:2.3.eng: And how is a mendicant mindful?

sn47.2:2.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.2:2.4.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.2:2.5.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.2:2.7.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.2:2.7.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.2:2.8.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sato hoti.
sn47.2:2.8.eng: That’s how a mendicant is mindful.

sn47.2:3.1.eng: And how is a mendicant aware?

sn47.2:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hoti, ālokite vilokite sampajānakārī hoti, samiñjite pasārite sampajānakārī hoti, saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇe sampajānakārī hoti, asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajānakārī hoti, uccārapassāvakamme sampajānakārī hoti, gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī hoti.
sn47.2:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant acts with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.

sn47.2:3.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sampajānakārī hoti.
sn47.2:3.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant acts with situational awareness.

sn47.2:3.4.eng: A mendicant should live mindful and aware.

sn47.2:3.5.eng: This is my instruction to you.”

sn47.20:0.3.eng: The Finest Lady in the Land

sn47.20:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sumbhesu viharati sedakaṃ nāma sumbhānaṃ nigamo.
sn47.20:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sumbhas, near the town of the Sumbhas named Sedaka.

sn47.20:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

sn47.20:2.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ‘janapadakalyāṇī, janapadakalyāṇī’ti kho, bhikkhave, mahājanakāyo sannipateyya.
sn47.20:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, suppose that on hearing, ‘The finest lady in the land! The finest lady in the land!’ a large crowd would gather.

sn47.20:2.2.pli: ‘Sā kho panassa janapadakalyāṇī paramapāsāvinī nacce, paramapāsāvinī gīte.
sn47.20:2.2.eng: And the finest lady in the land would dance and sing in a most thrilling way.

sn47.20:2.3.pli: Janapadakalyāṇī naccati gāyatī’ti kho, bhikkhave, bhiyyoso mattāya mahājanakāyo sannipateyya.
sn47.20:2.3.eng: On hearing, ‘The finest lady in the land is dancing and singing! The finest lady in the land is dancing and singing!’ an even larger crowd would gather.

sn47.20:2.4.pli: Atha puriso āgaccheyya jīvitukāmo amaritukāmo sukhakāmo dukkhappaṭikūlo.
sn47.20:2.4.eng: Then a person would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain.

sn47.20:2.6.pli: ‘ayaṃ te, ambho purisa, samatittiko telapatto antarena ca mahāsamajjaṃ antarena ca janapadakalyāṇiyā pariharitabbo.
sn47.20:2.6.eng: ‘Worthy man, this is a bowl full to the brim with oil. You must carry it in between this large crowd and the finest lady in the land.

sn47.20:2.7.pli: Puriso ca te ukkhittāsiko piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhissati.
sn47.20:2.7.eng: And a man with a drawn sword will follow right behind you.

sn47.20:2.8.pli: Yattheva naṃ thokampi chaḍḍessati tattheva te siro pātessatī’ti.
sn47.20:2.8.eng: Wherever you spill even a drop, he’ll chop off your head right there.’

sn47.20:2.10.pli: api nu so puriso amuṃ telapattaṃ amanasikaritvā bahiddhā pamādaṃ āhareyyā”ti?
sn47.20:2.10.eng: Would that person lose focus on that bowl, and negligently get distracted outside?”

sn47.20:3.1.pli: “Upamā kho myāyaṃ, bhikkhave, katā atthassa viññāpanāya.
sn47.20:3.1.eng: “I’ve made up this simile to make a point.

sn47.20:3.2.eng: And this is what it means.

sn47.20:3.3.pli: samatittiko telapattoti kho, bhikkhave, kāyagatāya etaṃ satiyā adhivacanaṃ.
sn47.20:3.3.eng: ‘A bowl of oil filled to the brim’ is a term for mindfulness of the body.

sn47.20:3.4.eng: So you should train like this:

sn47.20:3.5.pli: ‘kāyagatā sati no bhāvitā bhavissati bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā’ti.
sn47.20:3.5.eng: ‘We will develop mindfulness of the body. We’ll cultivate it, make it our vehicle and our basis, keep it up, consolidate it, and properly implement it.’

sn47.21:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ca ānando āyasmā ca bhaddo pāṭaliputte viharanti kukkuṭārāme.
sn47.21:1.2.eng: At one time the venerables Ānanda and Bhadda were staying near Pāṭaliputta, in the Chicken Monastery.

sn47.21:1.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā bhaddo sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā ānandena saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn47.21:1.3.eng: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Bhadda came out of retreat, went to Venerable Ānanda, and exchanged greetings with him.

sn47.21:1.4.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā bhaddo āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:
sn47.21:1.4.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to Ānanda:

sn47.21:1.5.pli: “yānimāni, āvuso ānanda, kusalāni sīlāni vuttāni bhagavatā, imāni kusalāni sīlāni kimatthiyāni vuttāni bhagavatā”ti?
sn47.21:1.5.eng: “Reverend Ānanda, the Buddha has spoken of skillful ethics. What’s their purpose?”

sn47.21:2.2.pli: Bhaddako kho te, āvuso bhadda, ummaṅgo, bhaddakaṃ paṭibhānaṃ, kalyāṇī paripucchā.
sn47.21:2.2.eng: Your approach and articulation are excellent, and it’s a good question.

sn47.21:2.4.pli: ‘yānimāni, āvuso ānanda, kusalāni sīlāni vuttāni bhagavatā, imāni kusalāni sīlāni kimatthiyāni vuttāni bhagavatā’”ti?
sn47.21:2.4.eng: ‘The Buddha has spoken of skillful ethics. What’s their purpose?’”

sn47.21:2.6.pli: “Yānimāni, āvuso bhadda, kusalāni sīlāni vuttāni bhagavatā, imāni kusalāni sīlāni yāvadeva catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvanāya vuttāni bhagavatā.
sn47.21:2.6.eng: “The Buddha has spoken of skillful ethics to the extent necessary for developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn47.21:3.2.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.21:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.21:3.3.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.21:3.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.21:3.5.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.21:3.6.pli: Yānimāni, āvuso bhadda, kusalāni sīlāni vuttāni bhagavatā, imāni kusalāni sīlāni yāvadeva imesaṃ catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvanāya vuttāni bhagavatā”ti.
sn47.21:3.6.eng: The Buddha has spoken of skillful ethics to the extent necessary for developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.”

sn47.22:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā bhaddo āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:

sn47.22:1.3.pli: “ko nu kho, āvuso ānanda, hetu, ko paccayo yena tathāgate parinibbute saddhammo na ciraṭṭhitiko hoti?
sn47.22:1.3.eng: “What is the cause, Reverend Ānanda, what is the reason why the true teaching does not last long after the final quenching of the Realized One?

sn47.22:1.4.pli: Ko panāvuso ānanda, hetu, ko paccayo yena tathāgate parinibbute saddhammo ciraṭṭhitiko hotī”ti?
sn47.22:1.4.eng: What is the cause, what is the reason why the true teaching does last long after the final quenching of the Realized One?”

sn47.22:2.2.pli: Bhaddako kho te, āvuso bhadda, ummaṅgo, bhaddakaṃ paṭibhānaṃ, kalyāṇī paripucchā.
sn47.22:2.2.eng: Your approach and articulation are excellent, and it’s a good question.

sn47.22:2.4.pli: ‘ko nu kho, āvuso ānanda, hetu, ko paccayo yena tathāgate parinibbute saddhammo na ciraṭṭhitiko hoti?
sn47.22:2.4.eng: ‘What is the cause, Reverend Ānanda, what is the reason why the true teaching does not last long after the final quenching of the Realized One?

sn47.22:2.5.pli: Ko panāvuso ānanda, hetu, ko paccayo yena tathāgate parinibbute saddhammo ciraṭṭhitiko hotī’”ti?
sn47.22:2.5.eng: What is the cause, what is the reason why the true teaching does last long after the final quenching of the Realized One?’”

sn47.22:2.7.pli: “Catunnaṃ kho, āvuso, satipaṭṭhānānaṃ abhāvitattā abahulīkatattā tathāgate parinibbute saddhammo na ciraṭṭhitiko hoti.
sn47.22:2.7.eng: “It’s because of not developing and cultivating the four kinds of mindfulness meditation that the true teaching doesn’t last long after the final quenching of the Realized One.

sn47.22:2.8.pli: Catunnañca kho, āvuso, satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā tathāgate parinibbute saddhammo ciraṭṭhitiko hoti.
sn47.22:2.8.eng: It’s because of developing and cultivating the four kinds of mindfulness meditation that the true teaching does last long after the final quenching of the Realized One.

sn47.22:3.2.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.22:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.22:3.3.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.22:3.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.22:3.5.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.22:3.6.pli: Imesaṃ kho, āvuso, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ abhāvitattā abahulīkatattā tathāgate parinibbute saddhammo na ciraṭṭhitiko hoti.
sn47.22:3.6.eng: It’s because of not developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation that the true teaching doesn’t last long after the final quenching of the Realized One.

sn47.22:3.7.pli: Imesañca kho, āvuso, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā tathāgate parinibbute saddhammo ciraṭṭhitiko hotī”ti.
sn47.22:3.7.eng: It’s because of developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation that the true teaching does last long after the final quenching of the Realized One.”

sn47.23:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ca ānando āyasmā ca bhaddo pāṭaliputte viharanti kukkuṭārāme.
sn47.23:1.1.eng: At one time the venerables Ānanda and Bhadda were staying near Pāṭaliputta, in the Chicken Monastery.

sn47.23:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā bhaddo sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā ānandena saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn47.23:1.2.eng: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Bhadda came out of retreat, went to Venerable Ānanda, and exchanged greetings with him.

sn47.23:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā bhaddo āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:
sn47.23:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to Ānanda:

sn47.23:1.4.pli: “ko nu kho, āvuso ānanda, hetu, ko paccayo yena saddhammaparihānaṃ hoti?
sn47.23:1.4.eng: “What’s the cause, Reverend Ānanda, what’s the reason why the true teaching declines?

sn47.23:1.5.pli: Ko nu kho, āvuso ānanda, hetu, ko paccayo yena saddhammaaparihānaṃ hotī”ti?
sn47.23:1.5.eng: And what’s the cause, what’s the reason why the true teaching doesn’t decline?”

sn47.23:2.2.pli: Bhaddako kho te, āvuso bhadda, ummaṅgo, bhaddakaṃ paṭibhānaṃ, kalyāṇī paripucchā.
sn47.23:2.2.eng: Your approach and articulation are excellent, and it’s a good question.

sn47.23:2.4.pli: ‘ko nu kho, āvuso ānanda, hetu, ko paccayo yena saddhammaparihānaṃ hoti?
sn47.23:2.4.eng: ‘What’s the cause, what’s the reason why the true teaching declines?

sn47.23:2.5.pli: Ko panāvuso ānanda, hetu, ko paccayo yena saddhammaaparihānaṃ hotī’”ti?
sn47.23:2.5.eng: And what’s the cause, what’s the reason why the true teaching doesn’t decline?’”

sn47.23:2.7.pli: “Catunnaṃ kho, āvuso, satipaṭṭhānānaṃ abhāvitattā abahulīkatattā saddhammaparihānaṃ hoti.
sn47.23:2.7.eng: “It’s because of not developing and cultivating the four kinds of mindfulness meditation that the true teaching declines.

sn47.23:2.8.pli: Catunnañca kho, āvuso, satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā saddhammaaparihānaṃ hoti.
sn47.23:2.8.eng: It’s because of developing and cultivating the four kinds of mindfulness meditation that the true teaching doesn’t decline.

sn47.23:3.2.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.23:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.23:3.3.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.23:3.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.23:3.5.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.23:3.6.pli: Imesaṃ kho, āvuso, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ abhāvitattā abahulīkatattā saddhammaparihānaṃ hoti.
sn47.23:3.6.eng: It’s because of not developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation that the true teaching declines.

sn47.23:3.7.pli: Imesañca kho, āvuso, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā saddhammaaparihānaṃ hotī”ti.
sn47.23:3.7.eng: And it’s because of developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation that the true teaching doesn’t decline.”

sn47.24:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn47.24:1.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.24:1.4.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.24:1.5.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.24:1.7.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.24:1.7.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.24:1.8.eng: These are the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.”

sn47.25:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn47.25:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn47.25:1.3.pli: Atha kho aññataro brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn47.25:1.3.eng: Then a certain brahmin went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

sn47.25:1.4.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn47.25:1.4.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

sn47.25:1.5.pli: “ko nu kho, bho gotama, hetu, ko paccayo yena tathāgate parinibbute saddhammo na ciraṭṭhitiko hoti?
sn47.25:1.5.eng: “What is the cause, worthy Gotama, what is the reason why the true teaching does not last long after the final quenching of the Realized One?

sn47.25:1.6.pli: Ko pana, bho gotama, hetu, ko paccayo yena tathāgate parinibbute saddhammo ciraṭṭhitiko hotī”ti?
sn47.25:1.6.eng: And what is the cause, what is the reason why the true teaching does last long after the final quenching of the Realized One?”

sn47.25:2.1.pli: “Catunnaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, satipaṭṭhānānaṃ abhāvitattā abahulīkatattā tathāgate parinibbute saddhammo na ciraṭṭhitiko hoti.
sn47.25:2.1.eng: “Brahmin, it’s because of not developing and cultivating the four kinds of mindfulness meditation that the true teaching doesn’t last long after the final quenching of the Realized One.

sn47.25:2.2.pli: Catunnañca kho, brāhmaṇa, satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā tathāgate parinibbute saddhammo ciraṭṭhitiko hoti.
sn47.25:2.2.eng: It’s because of developing and cultivating the four kinds of mindfulness meditation that the true teaching does last long after the final quenching of the Realized One.

sn47.25:3.2.pli: Idha, brāhmaṇa, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.25:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.25:3.3.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.25:3.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.25:3.5.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.25:3.6.pli: Imesaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ abhāvitattā abahulīkatattā tathāgate parinibbute saddhammo na ciraṭṭhitiko hoti.
sn47.25:3.6.eng: It’s because of not developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation that the true teaching doesn’t last long after the final quenching of the Realized One.

sn47.25:3.7.pli: Imesañca kho, brāhmaṇa, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā tathāgate parinibbute saddhammo ciraṭṭhitiko hotī”ti.
sn47.25:3.7.eng: It’s because of developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation that the true teaching does last long after the final quenching of the Realized One.”

sn47.25:4.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, so brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn47.25:4.1.eng: When he said this, the brahmin said to the Buddha,

sn47.25:4.3.pli: upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
sn47.25:4.3.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
